6.29.text:
Ancestry reckon there are about 11 million
people in the UK who have ancestors who fought

11.93.text:
at the Battle of the Somme, although they
may not know it.

15.65.text:
To help us find out more about our ancestors'
service in World War One and in particular, at the Somme,

22.09.text:
I've come here in The National Archives to
talk to Simon Pearce from Ancestry ProGenealogists

29.38.text:
who's an expert in military family history
research.

33.46.text:
Right Simon, so how do we get started? Can
we just go to a database, type in our ancestor's

38.92.text: name, press a key and whoosh - off we go?

41.31.text:
Unfortunately, it's not quite that simple.
Like with any type of family history research,

45.72.text:
the big issue here is going to be piecing
together a number of different resources.

49.48.text:
First and foremost to establish whether or
not your ancestor even served during the

52.78.text: First World War, before we can work out where they served.

55.72.text:
Then we can really start deducting whether
or not they served on The Somme.

58.66.text:
The key issue here is going to be tying together
a number of different dates and locations

63.12.text:
using a variety of different sources. First
and foremost, it's really important you consult

67.88.text:
our Service and Pension Records collection
and our Medal Cards and Medal Rolls because these

71.81.text:
will provide you with a fantastic platform
for your research.

74.52.text: What other key resources would be helpful?

77.08.text:
The War Diaries are a really fantastic source
to start with. The keeping of these diaries

80.88.text:
was compulsory for a number of different battalions
and units during the First World War and if

85.33.text:
you look at the extracts from certain units
of the opening day of The Somme, on the 1st of July

89.52.text:
1916, you'll notice that the extracts are particularly
lengthy and insightful and in-depth and they

94.31.text:
really do bring home the horror and the tragedy
of this bloody day in British military history.

99.03.text:
If you know that your ancestor was killed
in action, or died of wounds on a particular

103.29.text:
date, or even wounded on a particular date,
you should look them up in the diary because often

106.85.text:
it can tell you where they were stationed,
what they were doing, what they were experiencing.

110.32.text:
It's a really fantastic piece of context you
can gather from this source.

114.03.text:
I'd also advise that you go to the end of
each month in the diary, because often there are

117.82.text: appendices which have maps, casualty lists, and official orders that can give you a really

122.35.text:
interesting insight into your ancestor's experiences 
on the Somme.

125.52.text:
Presumably, the casualties and the dead were
specifically listed though?

130.17.text:
Yes, that's correct. You can find these casualties
on the Commonwealth War Graves Commission website.

134.30.text:
In terms of Ancestry records, I'd
suggest that you go to the Soldiers Effects collection.

139.95.text:
This is a record collection that details any
money or war gratuities that were paid to

143.42.text:
the next of kin of a soldier who died while
serving with the British Army.

147.18.text:
From a genealogical point of view, this is
a fantastic source because it can tell you

150.28.text:
the next of kin for the soldier who was paid
the money. From a military point of you, it's

154.17.text:
very useful because if you're one of the unlucky
40% whose ancestors' records were destroyed,

159.61.text:
it can have extra titbits of information not
found elsewhere. If an individual died of

163.85.text:
wounds, occasionally it will record the stationary
hospital or the field ambulance that they

167.51.text:
died at. Then you can get the war diary for
this particular unit.

170.86.text:
I'd also advise you look up your ancestors
who were taken prisoner or who were initially

174.45.text:
deemed to have died and then later turned
up, because occasionally they are recorded

181.55.text:
In terms of casualties, it's also worth checking
De Ruvigny's Roll of Honour. This is a collection

186.04.text:
of 26,000 biographies of casualties in the
First World War, 7,000 of which contained photographs.

191.55.text:
From a genealogical and military point of
view, it's incredibly useful and quite poignant too.

195.68.text:
Presumably, we've got specific records of
the prisoner's of war.

199.49.text:
Yes, we have Officers Records. A number of
men were taken prisoner on the opening day

203.51.text:
of the Somme and throughout the offensive
as a whole, whether or not they were officers

206.72.text:
or from the ranks. The record collection that we
have will tell you their name, their unit, their rank,

212.06.text:
where they were captured, when they were
captured and when they were repatriated.

216.10.text: So it's a really fantastic source to consult.

219.12.text:
It wasn't just the English and the Scots and
the Welsh who were fighting though.

223.16.text: There was a lot of Irish there.

224.58.text:
Of course, there was plenty of Irish soldiers
there as well and of course though,

228.26.text:
during the First World War, they were considered British
soldiers. And all of the records we've discussed

231.60.text:
today are relevant for the Irish soldiers.
But there are some specific collections as well.

235.57.text:
You have the 'Irish Casualties of the
First World War' database which is worth consulting.

241.70.text:
I would suggest that it's important that we
acknowledge the role of the Royal Naval Division

245.98.text:
during the Somme offensive, particularly in
the final month where they suffered horrendous

249.09.text:
casualties at Ancre. We have the Royal Naval
Division Casualty Index which has extracted

254.56.text:
service information which is very useful.
I'd also advise that you consult the International

260.08.text:
Committee of the Red Cross's Prisoner of War
database because this has really useful prisoner

263.63.text:
of war information about soldiers that were
taken prisoner, where they were taken prisoner,

267.56.text:
where they were held, if they wounded, when
they were repatriated.

271.34.text: So that's a really fantastic resource.

273.16.text:
I'd also advise that if you're researching
an officer, you should come here to The National Archives

277.17.text:
because their Service Records are
held here and they're particularly lengthy

280.04.text:
and they really do vary in content from the
other ranks and records.

283.77.text:
Thanks a lot, Simon. I hope that was really
useful, whether you've just started off with

288.73.text:
your research or if you're very experienced
but hit a brick wall.

295.38.text: Good luck with your researching from us and goodbye.
